text: Jann hadn't actually done anything. He had just made his way over to her, with a gleam in his eye, and then he had stood silently behind her, showing more sensitivity than Acanà would have given him credit for under the circumstances. Nothing else had happened - just this, and his hand brushing her shoulder for a moment. For Aruna and all the others who knew her better, of course, that was enough. Acanà had recognized it immediately from her friend's grim expression as well as the understanding smile on Thonash's face. But whether Akayu had realized under the given circumstances what a striking change had happened during the night, she dared to doubt.

She said nothing. He would understand soon enough how little she intended to fulfill his image of the princess on the glass throne, and she didn't want to wake any sleeping dogs today. Today she was just happy, feeling Jann's presence behind her with every fiber of her body and enjoying the moment without fear. Of course there would be consequences, of course people would react with consternation, perhaps even anger, but at least with alienation. The difference between her and her young lover was too great - although Acanà actually felt completely differently after that night: Jann and she were one, much more than all these people would ever realize.

But she said nothing, and Jann remained inconspicuous. He didn't move from his seat, waiting in silence until the others left the room one by one - Thonash grinning, Akayu happy and Aruna visibly dissatisfied. It was only when the doors had closed behind them that Jann came back to life. He stepped right behind them and leaned over them.
‘Hello,’ he said affectionately.
‘Hello,’ she replied just as lovingly, tilting her head back and looking up at him. He leaned further forward and kissed her.

They did nothing else for a few moments, remaining in this kiss, in their togetherness. Then Acanà had to smile, because it did feel strange to kiss someone the wrong way round, and Jann seemed to feel the same way, because he began to grin under her lips. Nevertheless, neither of them let go until the smile turned into a giggle, then a laugh. Jann lifted his head, hastily kissed her nose again and straightened up. Acanà grabbed his hand and pulled him towards her on the bench.
‘Are you all right?’ she asked as if in passing.
He shrugged his shoulders.
‘I'm fine,’ he replied, ‘after all, I had a wonderful night. However, I would like to complain. You weren't there when I woke up this morning.’
‘Of course I was there,’ she returned, amused, ‘the first time, at least. What can I do if you fall asleep again?’
‘The night was exhausting,’ he explained, grinning as she threatened to headbutt him.
‘All right,’ he sighed, ‘I realize you've been busy. And I very much suspect that you will continue to be busy?’

He knew it, of course, she could see it in his eyes. Her tasks in Anabellánia were many and varied, and she was still far from having made up for the damage caused by her long absence. He knew it - and yet he secretly hoped it would be different. She was bound to disappoint him.

‘Unfortunately,’ she said regretfully, ‘now that we have a plan and everyone agrees, we also have to create the conditions for it. I have a meeting with the Council of Wise Men, and I'm sure Akayu will want to clarify a few things then. There's also a delegation from the north, Udele is giving a small reception, and I ...’ She broke off, unsure.
Jann looked at her, silent, all teasing gone from his eyes.
‘I see,’ he said softly, becoming completely serious, ‘when will I see you?’

She remained silent as she desperately thought about where she could squeeze in five minutes for him, where there was enough time for him in this overcrowded schedule. She became increasingly unhappy the longer she brooded.
‘It's just...’ she finally said gloomily, ‘right now, I mean... oh Jann! I don't know either!’
He paused for a moment, then smiled and pulled her close.
‘At least you've had time for me now,’ he said, ‘Acanà, things will calm down eventually, won't they?’

‘I'm sure,’ she assured him, relieved that he wasn't making a scene, ‘as soon as things are sorted out with Akayu, and then Anabellánia will take up less time in the future, and...’ She broke off, again despondent at the number of things that still needed to be sorted out. She took a deep breath.
‘Listen, my love,’ she said curtly, ‘I really don't know what time it's going to be. Why don't you wait for me in my room? That way, we'll definitely see each other again today.’
Jann hesitated for a moment, then smiled again, leaned forward and kissed her gently on the cheek.
‘All right, Acanà,’ he said quietly.

She had a guilty conscience towards him and, quite apart from that, she would have loved to lock herself away with him for a week anyway, to be completely absorbed in her new partnership. But she couldn't, they both knew that. No matter how much her own longing tugged at her, she could be glad that Jann was sensible enough to accept her limited time.

She had no idea how he had spent the day, nor did she have the leisure to ask anyone about him, but when she got to her room late at night - later than she had thought and much later than she had hoped - he was there, as promised.

It was already dark at night and Jann had obviously fallen asleep while waiting. He lay in her bed, undressed under the thin sheets, slumbering sweetly and blissfully. She stood still for a moment, looking at him, strangely moved by the sight of him. Then she took hold of herself and quietly scurried to her mirrored table to quickly and silently remove her jewelry, loosen her hair and slip into a light shirt.

As soon as she had finished, she climbed in next to him. Jann slept on peacefully, lying on his back, his face open and relaxed, one arm over his head. She smiled, scooted closer and gently stroked his bare chest with her hand. He murmured, but didn't wake up, and that encouraged her to caress him further. She pressed small, loving kisses onto his skin while her hand made ever larger circles, removing the sheet piece by piece. She carefully worked her way up to his navel, and when her tongue darted in cheekily, she felt his hand in her hair.
‘Hey,’ muttered Jann.
She lifted her head a little and blinked at him.
‘You know,’ she said in a chatty tone, ‘in Anabellánia it's like this: everything the mistress finds in her bed belongs to her from then on.’
‘Is that so?’ he replied doubtfully, ‘not that I want to protest in this case, but ...’

‘Of course it is,’ she said quickly, ‘or at least it is tonight. It's a law I've just passed. Anything - or anyone - who lies in my bed is mine. You put yourself at my mercy, Jann Deren.’ She leaned down again and kissed his navel.
‘Mmmh,’ he said, ‘all right, but...’
‘You won't regret it,’ she added with a wink and let her hand slide to its destination.

Jann gave only a stifled moan, and she savored the power she had over him, the heady sensation of feeling his body under her fingers, and the bliss of knowing they belonged together. But then he caught himself, one demanding arm slipped around her waist, another under her legs, and before she knew it, she was on her back.

The night before, he had been more urgent. A certain desperation had dominated his every movement; the overwhelming desire to convince her of himself had driven him, and she had sensed it. His vulnerability had touched her, as had his willingness to give himself to her completely, to hold nothing back, to hide nothing from her. Jann had given himself to her completely last night.

That night he was safer, he knew of their mutual love and was able to draw strength from it. He was determined to discover her, to enjoy her, and he took all the time in the world to do so. Whereas the night before he had done everything he could to convince her, this night it seemed to her as if he wanted to make his mark on her, to make her completely his so that he would never lose her again. During the day she might belong to others, but now, in the darkness, she was his.  She understood that, understood his longing, his need and she marveled at the skill and strength with which he acted. She was only too happy to give in to him and, when he finally fell asleep peacefully in her arms, she felt how important it had been for him, how much it had calmed him down. One night alone counted for nothing - Samaya had already proved that - but a second night was something completely different.

Like the day before, she was the first to wake, but this time he didn't stir as she slipped out of bed to face the many demands of the day. She didn't have the heart to wake him and just stood there for a moment, gazing at him tenderly and wishing she could climb back under the sheets. Before the wish became too pressing, she turned and left the room.
Outside, in the hallway, she met Tajla, a pile of laundry in her arms.
‘You're awake, mistress?’ she greeted the palace master's daughter kindly, ‘Good, because I was just about to wake you up. I wanted to bring this to your room and ask you ...’
Acanà interrupted her by placing a hand on Tajla's arm.
‘We can talk about it later,’ she said, ‘Akayu is waiting for me.’
‘He hasn't even had breakfast yet,’ Tajla replied with a shrug, ‘I just wanted to know if you wanted to keep these things. They are from your journey.’
Acanà paused. Of course, it was the tattered pants and the patched tunic she had worn until they had conquered Anabellánia. She had received the tunic from Derjam, she remembered. Her face softened.
‘Yes,’ she said, ‘I know I might not wear them again, but still ...’

‘I see,’ Tajla explained with a wink, ‘I already thought of something like that, that's why I wanted to ask you. I'll put them in the little chest in your room, shall I? Then you'll know where to find them.’
‘Thank you,’ Acanà replied automatically. But when Tajla stepped past her, she suddenly remembered and grabbed her arm.
‘Wait,’ she said, ‘don't go in yet. I mean ... go later.’
‘Why?’ asked Tajla, puzzled, ‘where am I supposed to leave the things for so long?’
‘Well,’ explained Acanà, a little embarrassed, ‘it's just that he's still asleep. I didn't want to wake him.’
Tajla looked at her, her eyes wide.
‘Who?’ she asked quietly.
Acanà returned her gaze openly.
‘Jann,’ she said.
Tajla's eyes widened a little more. For a moment, they just looked at each other, without words. Then Tajla nodded understandingly.

‘I understand,’ she said, ‘but if he's still asleep, he should be woken up soon anyway. Bajul wants to leave and has already asked for him. I can... I can check on Akayu first and see if he needs anything else, and then I'll go to your room. If Jann is still asleep, I can wake him up. At least then he'll have a little more time.’
Acanà bit her lips briefly before nodding.
‘Yes,’ she said, ‘that's probably a good compromise.’

Tajla did as she had suggested to Acanà. She tucked her mistress's traveling wardrobe under her arm without further ado - folds and creases really didn't matter here - marched up to Akayu and asked if she could help him. She had done so from the start - not only because she had hoped for Acanà that Akayu would feel comfortable in Anabellánia and perhaps want to stay, but also because she wanted to. After all, she had realized on the first evening who Jann's interest was, and she was not one to set her heart on a lost cause.

Jann and Acanà ... Well, it was certainly what the boy had wished for, but still. He was just a boy, an orphaned peasant child from Raja, and when you saw him, it was hard to believe that he had really done all the things the legends said he had. People would have a hard time accepting him, of all people, at the mistress's side. Akayu would certainly have problems with that - hopefully he wouldn't change his mind and leave in the end! No, that couldn't happen, not if she had a say in the matter! Akayu had to stay - she would see to that.

Jann and Acanà ... Quite apart from her own interests, Tajla also felt a little strange about the whole thing, because the two of them seemed too different. But after all, she knew that Jann had dreamed of nothing else, she wasn't blind - and she had never seen Acanà look as radiant as she did that morning.
Jann and Acanà ... Well, as far as she, Tajla, was concerned, she would be able to cope.

So she was actually more curious than embarrassed when she entered Acanà's room half an hour later. She could make out a motionless mound under the sheets in the bed - Jann had clearly not woken up yet.

The first thing she did was go into the small adjoining room to put the clothes away and tidy up a bit, because she wasn't quite sure how she was going to wake him up. But her rummaging around did the trick all by itself. She hadn't been there long when a hoarse, sleepy voice came from the bed.
‘Acanà?’
Tajla straightened up.
‘No, it's me,’ she replied as cheerfully as possible, ‘Acanà is already downstairs. Did you sleep well?’ She would have liked to bite her tongue for that last part.

Her presence was probably not quite what Jann had expected. It was completely silent for a moment, then she heard hasty rustling, as if someone was feverishly arranging the blankets. She would have liked to tell him that she hadn't seen anything, absolutely nothing, that he hadn't wanted to show her.
‘Yes,’ Jann said with some delay, ‘is it ... what time is it?’

Tajla thought it was silly to hide in the chamber and stepped back into the main room. He was sitting up in bed, the blankets actually gathered around him, though he refrained from prudishly pressing them to his bare chest. His hair was tousled and he looked caught out, although he was clearly trying to appear nonchalant.
‘It's still early,’ she reassured him, ‘but Bajul was looking for you and Acanà and I thought it would be better not to let you sleep too long.’
‘Oh, right,’ said Jann, ‘then ... I'd better get up.’
He didn't move, and Tajla realized that he wouldn't make a move as long as she was in the same room. She turned towards the door, but paused before pressing the handle.
‘Listen, Jann,’ she began, ‘should we move your things over? I mean, if you want us to, we'll have it moved very quickly.’

Was it still too early for that? But he seemed so insecure that she wanted him to know that she at least had no problem with his presence between those sheets. There would be plenty of others who would feel differently.
‘Um,’ he said sheepishly, ‘I don't know. Acanà ... we didn't ... later, maybe? I mean ... not today?’
Tajla looked at him, then smiled.
‘Of course,’ she said softly, ‘just let me know.’
And as she left the room, she thought to herself - by the sisters, my little one, you should become more self-confident as soon as possible, otherwise you're in for hard times!
And Jann, in the room, basically wished for nothing else.
There were a few things he had simply never thought about.

Jann had only ever dreamed up to the moment when Acanà would finally give in to his wishes, never beyond that. He had never thought about the fact that she was not only responsible for herself, but also for a whole bunch of other people, and that all these people, including her friends, would have something to say about it. He had simply never thought about the normal everyday life he would lead alongside the mistress of Anabellánia.
And it was frighteningly unpleasant.

He hadn't noticed any of this the day before. He had literally been in a cloud of bliss and pride, so that all the faces seemed to him as if they were looking through absorbent cotton. Of course he had seen Thonash's indulgent smile, as well as Caro's impudent grin and the frown line on Aruna's forehead - but he hadn't thought about the consequences. He had simply been too happy.

The first thing that had brought him back down to earth a little was the fact that Acanà had no time for him. But even that hadn't had too much of an impact on Jann, because he had simply avoided the others. If he couldn't have them by his side, he preferred to keep to himself. However, Tajla's appearance at his bedside had made it clear to him, like a splash of cold water, that he couldn't avoid reality forever.

It wasn't Acanà herself that unsettled him. He knew Acanà the person, the creature, who she really was, better than anyone else. Acanà was Acanà, his friend, his companion, his lover. But unfortunately for the world, she was more than just that. And now that they were no longer traveling as a couple, when others made demands on them and had expectations, Jann became painfully aware of the gulf between them.
There was her family, from Mirja to old Alruthe and Sinaîs ...
There was her quality as Weega's student, the silent understanding that existed between her and Thonash and which he, Jann, would never be able to fully grasp ...

And there was her position as mistress of Anabellánia, as the icon of all those people who had waited so long for her and hoped for her salvation. Her long absence had reinforced her status as a fairy-tale princess in this land, he could see it clearly.

And he? The farm boy from Raja, descendant of a disreputable, battle-scarred race whose entire achievement consisted of slaughtering each other? Without any kinship, without influence and without any goods?
He preferred not to even mention the age difference.

So it was not Acanà herself who threw Jann into this sudden shock, but the realization of the image they had of her and that no one on Thurán would have seriously matched it. Compared to her, he was nobody; he could have won against Rawenzan a hundred times over. He didn't need Aruna's wrinkle of anger to realize that.

But Jann wouldn't have been Jann if he had crawled into a corner and pulled the covers over his head. Well, then he was a nobody, if you like. Well, then no one would let out a fanfare because Acanà had given in to his desire, so there would be no leaps of joy and salutes. So what? He was still sleeping in her bed! And as long as she wanted him there, he would continue to sleep there, no matter how wrinkled Aruna's entire forehead was and no matter how worried Tajla looked! That's right!
At least that was Jann's attitude as he got dressed and left the room in search of Bajul and breakfast - and preferably in exactly that order.
But the first person he met was Akayu.

Jann froze involuntarily and tried to press himself inconspicuously to the side. He was secretly afraid of Akayu's reaction, because he knew that the leader of the Steppe Riders had his own hopes for Acanà. And after all, who knew whether Akayu wouldn't end up dropping everything and abandoning Acanà just because he, Jann, was sleeping in her bed?
Akayu had noticed him and was waiting for him, so Jann plucked up his courage and approached the man as innocuously as possible.
‘Hey, kiddo,’ Akayu said, ‘have you seen the mistress?’

Jann almost choked and felt his ears start to burn. Damn it! That was nonsense! After all, it was she who made the decisions, and if she chose him, Jann, then he had every right in the world, then no one was allowed to dispute him, then ...
‘Jann?’ said Akayu, ‘hello? Have you seen Acanà today?’
Jann lifted his chin belligerently.
‘Tajla said she was downstairs,’ he explained, ‘she was already up when I woke up.’
‘Well then,’ Akayu said with a shrug, ‘tell me, don't you think Tajla was kind of weird today? She's been making weird hints the whole time.’
‘Tajla? Huh?’ Jann asked, thrown off balance.
‘Maybe I just imagined it,’ Akayu muttered, ‘whatever. Go on, kid, breakfast is in the hall. I'll find the mistress.’
Well, Jann thought to himself as he walked on, that wasn't so bad after all!

And then he realized that Akayu probably didn't know anything yet. The tumbleweed rider might be an excellent leader, but he wasn't quite as great and clever in other areas. If Tajla, who now knew for sure, had made obscure hints to Akayu, then Jann was well aware of what it had been about.
Akayu, on the other hand, didn't seem to realize it.

For a moment, Jann was tempted to run after Akayu and enlighten him, but he quickly changed his mind. Perhaps it was better not to wake sleeping dogs for the time being. In fact, wasn't it generally better to slowly get people used to the idea of him as Acanà's lover? Wouldn't that perhaps help? Who actually knew?

That was another thing Jann hadn't thought about before. Somehow he had imagined that the whole world would find out immediately and accept it, or something like that, or something like that. But Akayu had obviously not drawn the right conclusions from Jann's enamored grin and Acanà's beams, and that raised the question of who actually knew now - because neither he nor Acanà had said anything out loud.
There was Tajla, obviously, after all she had caught him in her mistress's bed. Good, but he didn't seem to have to worry about Tajla, she was trying to be as relaxed as possible with him. Who else?
There was Thonash, who always knew such things, and this time was guaranteed to be no exception. But Thonash was wise and tolerant - also no problem.
Aruna, with her frown line, was more of a problem. But knowing Aruna, she would speak to Acanà first and leave him alone. At least he hoped so.
Caro, on the other hand, if he remembered correctly, just seemed happy for him.
Did Domric and Bajul, his friends, actually know?

No, of course not, unless Caro had told them something, and he didn't believe that. Aruna certainly hadn't talked about it, Thonash would be careful not to gossip - and Bajul and Domric hardly had any contact with the others. They didn't know. Akayu didn't know. Wasn't it better to leave it that way for now?

Jann took only an apple from the breakfast buffet and left the palace in search of Bajul and Domric. He found them in the back courtyard, Bajul's bundle already packed, but he was still explaining a few holds to Domric before he left them.
‘Ah!’ Domric exclaimed as soon as he spotted Jann, ‘look, Bajul! The young gentleman has struggled out of bed!’
That was surprisingly close to the situation, so Jann couldn't avoid blushing a little. He tried to remain calm.
‘Don't start teasing me, kid,’ he said cockily, ‘my night...’ And then he broke off, embarrassed.
‘Whatever,’ said Bajul, obviously not interested, ‘I'm glad I still see you. Besides, you can help me for once. Domric just won't get it. Here Jann, take my arm.’
‘What are you doing?’ asked Jann as he obeyed.
Bajul didn't answer, there was a jolt, and if Jann hadn't countered quickly, he would have flown through the air in a high arc.
‘Blimey,’ puffed Bajul, ‘I didn't mean to do it like that. Jann, damn it, don't pinch me. Domric, look here ...’
Jann ignored his talk and dug his fingers even deeper into his friend's arm.
‘Can you tell me what this is supposed to be?’ he asked stubbornly.
‘He wants to show me the left turn with the wielder,’ Domric explained, ‘but personally I don't think he knows how to do it himself. Hey, Jann, how about letting us in on your secret?’
‘Which one?’ Jann blurted out, blushing again.
Domric looked at him in amazement.
‘Well,’ he said, ‘the one with the twist and that trick, how you always get out of the headlock. Triovan is very interested in that.’
‘That's right, Jann,’ Bajul said and let go, ‘I think they want to include it in the program. Will you show us how you do it?’

‘Sure,’ Jann replied, glad that they were still talking about wrestling, ‘although I can't imagine, Bajul, how anyone would put you in a headlock. Domric, on the other hand, might find it really useful.’
So instead of telling his two best friends about his new liaison, he gave them lessons instead. And he was actually quite happy about it and wanted to keep it that way.
Acanà threw a spanner in the works.
Acanà had already had a hectic morning when she came down to the courtyard.

First she had bumped into Akayu, who was confused and wanted to know whether Tajla was all right and whether she had also heard any of these strange hints. Then she had spent half an hour discussing trivialities with the Brinan Citizens' Council, and then more trivialities with the palace cook, and she secretly decided that the phase of the happy returnee with open ears for every problem was now over. She had to delegate, she needed people who could take tasks off her hands, because it was only a matter of time before Weega's call hit her. Akayu's position had to be fixed, and she silently decided to involve Tajla more in the organization of the palace so that she, Acanà, would have more time for her private life, and Tajla a little less. If she played it smart, she would find an invaluable ally in Tajla.
And now, to make matters worse, Aruna had also intercepted them.

Aruna was like a sister to her, but that didn't mean they didn't fight their battles. Of course, Aruna only thought of her best in everything she did, Acanà knew that. It was just stupid that what Aruna thought was her best and what Acanà thought was her best didn't always overlap. Jann, at least, did not belong in Aruna's catalog. And she didn't hide it either.
‘I'm not saying he's not in love with you,’ she said seriously, ‘or that he doesn't go the extra mile. I think he's something special, too. But he's only nineteen, Acanà! Let him grow up first!’
‘That's what I tried to do,’ Acanà replied grimly, ‘for as long as I could. Aruna, I don't want to discuss Jann.’
‘He'll cause you problems, as I'm sure you're aware,’ Aruna warned.
‘Oh? And what kind of problems?’ Acanà sneered.
‘Isn't it obvious? You are responsible for this country, you wanted it that way. And you're Weega's student. With all your duties, you can't afford to be distracted by the whims of half a child!’
‘Jann has no moods!’ Acanà said indignantly.
‘Are you so sure about that?’
‘What are you trying to say?’
‘I just want to warn you,’ Aruna shot back, ‘today he worships the ground you walk on, no doubt, even I can see that. But tomorrow? And the day after tomorrow?’
Acanà would have liked to say that Jann would never leave her, but she couldn't, because there were simply no guarantees.
‘If he really does change his mind, I'll worry about that when the time comes,’ she said coolly instead.

‘When the time comes?’ asked Aruna with raised eyebrows, ‘it will be too late. And have you thought about your people? They've had a bad few years, they need stability. If you're going to expose them to your constant disappearances, as Weega's student, then at least you shouldn't put a boy in front of them who can barely write his name!’

‘That's mean, Aruna!’ Acanà hissed indignantly, ‘Firstly, Jann is worth more than you pretend. And secondly, he's my private life and nobody's business. My father took an elf as his wife and lived well with it!’
‘Until she disappeared,’ Aruna said dryly.
Acanà gasped for air and turned white as lime.

‘You have no idea what you're saying,’ she whispered, ‘you ... well, you can't know. Incidentally, that's also something Jann has over you, my dear - he knows what happened to Mirja and he would never hurt me like that!’

‘I don't want to hurt you,’ Aruna gave in quickly, ‘you know that. But I also don't want you to be hurt in the future. Acanà, I just have a bad feeling. The boy will leave you and you will suffer, and I think... I think you've suffered enough already.’
Acanà stared at her, and then she smiled.

‘You can't know that,’ she said gently, ‘no one can know. How do you know if everything will be all right with you and Caro? Jann and I are going our own way. My decision has been made, Aruna. I don't want to discuss it any more.’
‘At least you're not inferior to him in stubbornness,’ grumbled Aruna, ‘then at least take it slowly. Wait a little. Don't jump in head first.’
By now they had reached the courtyard, where Jann was practicing with Bajul and Domric at the other end. Caro waved to them, engrossed in a conversation with Akayu, and Thonash was talking to Nalyne.
‘Acanà, please,’ sighed Aruna, ‘it's going to be hard enough. Take it slowly.’

Acanà turned around. Jann had seen her and straightened up. If she wasn't mistaken, there was a certain uncertainty in his eyes, a slight fear of how she would behave. The day before, she remembered, he had said nothing and had done nothing but stand behind her and put his hand on her shoulder.
‘Acanà?’ Aruna repeated.
‘No,’ Acanà said quietly, ‘I can't do that. I love him.’

And with that, she resolutely made her way to him, ahead of all her friends. Jann walked towards her until he reached the wooden fence that separated the training area from the rest of the yard. He leaned against the posts and smiled. Acanà smiled too, stepped closer and pulled his head down towards him.
‘Hello,’ she whispered and kissed him.

He faltered for a moment, she felt it under her fingers, before he gave in and returned the kiss. It seemed to have gone dead quiet behind her. She broke away a little. Jann's cheeks were flushed, his breathing a little too fast.
‘Did you miss me?’ she asked.
‘Yes,’ he replied, ‘and I would like to lodge another complaint.’
‘Really?’ she asked anxiously.
‘Exactly,’ he explained, reaching through the fence around her waist and lifting her onto the lowest rung so that she was at eye level with him and could put her arms around his neck.
‘I woke up and there was another woman at my bedside,’ he completed with a pout. She laughed out loud.
‘Another woman? Who?’
‘Tajla. She scared me.’
‘It was just to wake you up.’
‘I like it better when you wake me up.’
‘She shouldn't wake you up the way I do,’ she said with surging jealousy.
‘She didn't either,’ he quickly placated, ‘but ... but Acanà ... next time you'll do it, yes?’
She was a little guilty because she had left him again without saying goodbye.
‘You slept so peacefully,’ she said quietly.
‘Still, I'd rather not have experienced that,’ he said seriously, ‘I mean ... the palace master's daughter caught me in her mistress's bed ...’
She frowned.
‘I don't want to hide you, Jann,’ she said firmly.
He had to grin.
‘I hope so,’ he said, ‘besides, if you wanted that, it would all be too late now.’
‘You have to get used to situations like this,’ she added seriously.
His grin began to wobble.
‘I know,’ he mumbled, ‘but next time ... I'd just rather have my pants on, yeah?’
‘Oh!’ She understood and immediately felt guilty.
‘Oh!’ she repeated, ‘I'm sorry! Did she ... oh Jann! I hadn't been thinking!’
‘It's all right,’ he reassured her, ‘it wasn't that bad. But wake me up in the morning, will you? Provided you want me to sleep in your bed again. I can also ... I mean, you can come to me, or ...’

She heard his embarrassed stammering, saw his heated cheeks, and her heart softened. This was far more difficult for Jann than it was for her; she had to make it easier for him wherever she could, and she wanted to. She wouldn't give him up again just because a few people didn't approve of their future or didn't think it was suitable.

‘My bed is bigger,’ she said, ‘you're coming to me. From now on, I want to fall asleep in your arms every night and wake up next to you every morning. And then ...’ She leaned over and kissed him again lovingly.
‘Then I'll wake you up too,’ she completed gently.
His eyes darkened.
‘Like last night?’ he whispered.
‘If you want it?’ she returned half aloud.
They just looked at each other in silence for a moment, and this time it was Jann who leaned in and kissed her.

Her kiss had been tender, anything but sisterly, but chaste in a certain way despite everything. His was nothing of the sort, speaking of the passion of previous nights, of surging lust and overwhelming longing. She was breathless when he let go of her, her heart was pounding and she was at a loss for words. So she just ran her hand over his cheek once, detached herself and turned to go back to Aruna. Her friend was already waiting for her with a furrowed brow, but Acanà, with her racing pulse and intoxicating happiness, merely smiled in return.

Jann looked after her, a happy smile on his face as well. He was very warm, and for the moment he didn't care at all that everyone in the yard was staring at him, including Bajul and Domric. He was actually quite hot, so he let go of the wooden fence, marched to the horses' water trough and stuck his head in without further ado. When he came up again, snorting, Bajul and Domric were already waiting for him.
‘By the sisters, Jann...’ Bajul stammered, while Domric actually seemed at a loss for words and was still staring after Acanà, who had acknowledged Jann's reaction with a proud grin.
‘Yes?’ asked Jann harmlessly.
‘Tell me,’ Bajul stuttered on, ‘did you ... didn't you forget to mention something?’
‘Forget what?’ Jann replied innocently.
There was only silence for a few seconds. Then Domric regained his speech.
‘On him!’ he growled, and Jann could only let out a stunned squeak as his friends threw themselves over him with their combined strength.

Several laps through the sand, several pats and lots of laughter later, the three of them were sitting in the shade next to the stable, somewhat breathless and rather dirty, sharing a bottle of water.
‘Out with it!’ Domric demanded.
‘Yes, Jann,’ said Bajul, ‘tell me! What happened?’
‘And with all the dirty details!’ Domric added grimly.
Jann leaned back and sighed. Life, he felt at that moment, had been extremely good to him.
‘She came to me,’ he reported, emotion choking his voice. He cleared his throat and continued speaking more clearly, as Domric and Bajul merely stared at him in silence.

‘She ... she must have had some kind of nightmare or something,’ he explained, ‘she was all upset. That was the night before last. She knocked on my door - although, she probably didn't knock at all, she staggered against it.’ He gave a little laugh and shook his head.

‘She came to me,’ he repeated hoarsely, ‘Akayu and Thonash sleep on the same corridor as us, she could have sought comfort from either of them, and I bet they both would have given it to her, one way or another. But she came to me.’
‘And you gave her ... consoled her,’ Domric concluded dryly.
Jann blushed a little.

‘Well,’ he confessed, ‘she ... she knew what she wanted and I can't say that I put up any resistance. I was convinced very quickly. She was so desperate. She told me later that she wanted to feel that she was still alive.’
‘You gave her that feeling?’ asked Bajul.
Jann nodded proudly.
‘Yes. I was able to give her that feeling.’
‘And then she realized it?’ Domric wanted to know doubtfully.
Jann shook his head.

‘Not quite,’ he admitted, ‘I don't think Acanà was even aware of what she was doing. And afterwards she was completely still, as if she had fainted. I didn't know exactly what to do, but I thought anything was better than leaving her on the floor.’
‘On the ground!’ shouted Bajul.
Jann blushed again.

‘By the sisters!’ he defended himself, ‘when the woman of your dreams suddenly staggers into your arms at night and starts kissing you, do you seriously think you're still thinking much about finesse or time and place? You act!’
‘It's all right,’ Domric muttered, ‘I didn't want the details. Go on. So you didn't leave them on the floor.’

‘I carried her to my bed,’ Jann explained, ‘what else could I have done? I put her in my bed, covered her up and lay down next to her. Actually, I just wanted to look at her and wait for her to come to, but I fell asleep myself. And when I woke up ...’ His cheeks involuntarily grew warmer, remembering her gaze, his nakedness and the feeling of being at her mercy.

‘She looked at me,’ he completed harshly, ‘she was awake, she looked at me. I think it was the first time she really saw me as I am today, not as I was six years ago when she found me. Acanà has finally realized that I am no longer a child.’
He took a deep breath.

‘Then we talked,’ he continued, ‘I told her all the things I've wanted to tell her for so long, and she listened to it. I just thought, if I don't manage to convince her that night, I never will. I mean, honestly - she's known I loved her for over a year and I've always been close to her. It's probably the closest I'd ever get to her than the night before last.’
‘And it seems to have worked,’ said Domric.
Jann smiled.
‘It did,’ he whispered, ‘she told me. She gave in, she let me come to her. She told me she loved me.’ His voice almost broke on the last words.
‘And what luck that is,’ he added choked.
Bajul looked at him and smiled.
‘I'm sure you will,’ he said, ‘congratulations, Jann. You give me hope. But if anyone deserved it, it was you. You should hear what they say about you in the camp. Your loyalty is already legendary.’
‘Well,’ said Jann, clearing his throat, ‘let's hope that all those who want to make Acanà believe that I'm leaving her again will remember that.’
Akayu, who was standing unseen behind a pile of wood, turned around and left.
‘Did you know that?’ he asked Tajla, thundering his fist on the table next to her, ‘did you know about them? Were these the things you were talking about?’
Tajla looked up, startled. Akayu was pale, a vein in his temple was pulsating, and she suddenly realized what this was all about. Nevertheless, she preferred to play it safe.
‘What do you think?’ she asked with a dry mouth.
‘What am I supposed to mean!’ snorted Akayu, ‘What does she want with the boy? What's going on between her and the boy - and did everyone know that? Am I the only one who ...’
‘Wait, wait!’ she interrupted him hastily, ‘You're talking about Jann and Acanà, aren't you? If it makes you feel any better, I only found out about them this morning.’
‘Really?’ he growled.
Tajla forced a smile onto her face. She wasn't exactly tiny, like Acanà, but Akayu was very tall and very strong. And at the moment, he was also extremely angry.

‘This morning,’ she repeated, ‘I wanted to go into her room, but she held me back and told me he was still asleep. So it's still fresh, you see. I woke Jann up, and that was the first time. He hadn't spent the night before in her bed.’
Akayu visibly calmed down and took a deep breath.
‘Really fresh?’ he asked to make sure.
Tajla smiled with more confidence.
‘Exactly,’ she confirmed, ‘and I bet they've all been hit by it just like you.’
‘I'm not hit,’ he defended himself to save his pride, ‘I'm just ... surprised. I never expected this. I did think about whether she might be Thonash ... but Jann? Seriously - Jann?’
His tone of voice sounded completely different now - confused, a little helpless, and also a little hurt. Fortunately, Tajla saw the danger of Akayu losing control, sighed and sat down next to him.
‘It seems strange,’ she admitted, ‘I think so too. But is it really that surprising? I mean, Jann worships the ground she walks on, that was obvious.’
‘Was that it?’ Akayu murmured, ‘I thought he was just being faithful to her.’
She looked at him curiously.

‘Really?’ she asked, ‘didn't you ever notice that he was always around her? That he hardly had eyes for anyone else when she was in the room? That he looked after her when she left? Or walked with her if he could?’
‘Yes,’ he admitted, ‘but that was ... kind of normal.’
‘Because he's her shadow?’
‘Exactly. Well, Otaki made a few hints ... a young woman and an adolescent boy, all alone for months, yes, years ... But I didn't take it seriously.’

‘Thonash thinks Jann has loved Acanà longer than he realizes,’ she said, ‘and that Acanà has always felt much more for the boy than she wanted to admit to us and to herself. He knows her better than I do, and he sees more than we can. He will probably be right.’
‘I guess he will,’ he sighed, staring unhappily ahead of him, ‘I just wish I had ... oh, what the hell. She ... she looked very happy, didn't she?’
Tajla eyed him impressively.
‘Yes,’ she said softly, ‘she's very happy.’
‘She loves him,’ he whispered, ‘she told him.’
Tajla remained silent, waiting, but Akayu said nothing more. Then she took heart, cleared her throat and jumped into the cold water.
‘What does that mean for you now?’ she asked boldly.
Akayu lifted his head, torn from his thoughts.
‘What do you mean?’ he asked in surprise.
She fought hard against the telltale blush on her cheeks.
‘Are you still going to stay?’ she blurted out.
He stared at her in amazement for a moment, then blushed. He obviously didn't like the fact that she had seen through him. But something else had apparently hit him.

‘What makes you think,’ he said with dignity, ‘that I would make my decision dependent on that? Do you seriously think I would only help the mistress of Anabellánia if I could get her into my bed in return?’
He would not leave. Tajla registered it with a heavy surge of relief. Akayu would not go. She began to beam.
‘Sorry,’ she said happily, ‘that was stupid of me. I wasn't thinking.’
He noticed her joy with confusion at first, then it turned into amusement. Tajla didn't care.
‘Are you all right?’ he asked dryly as she continued to grin at him pointlessly.
‘Sure,’ claimed Tajla, beaming, ‘I'm just happy.’
And that was all she said for the time being.
Jann spent a very pleasant day.

Around midday, Bajul finally set off, full of hope that he would be able to impress Mery and reach his destination, just as Jann had succeeded in doing. Domric disappeared in the direction of Nalyne - albeit with much less hope - and Jann made his way back to the palace. Halfway there, he met Caro, who didn't say much, just grinned meaningfully and ruffled Jann's hair. But that alone was liberating - at least Caro had no problem with the small demonstration of affection.

Akayu, whom Jann met in the afternoon, probably had more of a problem with this. He spent a rather awkward half hour with the newly appointed deputy of Anabellánien, during which the latter wanted to know quite gruffly how Jann envisioned his future here, what tasks he wanted to perform and how long he intended to stay. Jann answered as honestly as possible, trying to make Akayu understand that he made no claims to governmental power, that he did not want to dispute Akayu's position in this regard, and, yes, that he intended to stay forever. Both of them were aware that it was subliminally about something completely different, but when this unpleasant half hour was over, Jann felt that he had overcome another hurdle.

Despite all this, he could not fail to notice, either now or in the days that followed, how people stared at him, how people whispered behind his back, and how much this had increased again. It unsettled him far more than he would have liked, and instead of openly confronting the rumors, refuting the mockers and showing strength, he avoided them, seeking the familiar presence of Caro and Domric, and after they had also left, often enough solitude.
However, he could not avoid Manaro.

Manaro had suffered a serious injury that had almost cost him his leg and left him with a high temperature for several days. But he was now on the mend and was preparing to leave. The wild rumors about the Lady of Anabellánia and her shadow had of course not stopped at his sickroom, and since Jann did not come, he sent for him.

One did not turn down an invitation from the most powerful lord of the Rashko, especially when he was the closest thing Jann had to a father figure. But Manaro was not only the man who had taken care of him so lovingly in K'Springen during the confusing weeks after Rawenzan's death, when he had felt lonely for completely different reasons - he had also been Derjam Klysion's best friend. And Jann felt very strongly that he was anything but a worthy successor to Derjam's position.
So he set off for Manaro with mixed feelings.

Manaro was waiting for him, sitting up in bed, busy with some papers and obviously fully recovered, apart from the broken leg. He looked up when Jann came in, and Jann noticed uneasily that Manaro wasn't smiling.
‘Hello,’ he said quickly, ‘I've neglected you. I'm sorry.’
‘That's all right,’ Manaro sighed and put the papers aside, ‘there are certainly more exciting things than the infirmary. Especially when you've become a young hero.’
That sounded understanding, not malicious, and so Jann didn't feel attacked.
‘Honestly,’ he said with a wry smile, ‘I don't know if I'm that comfortable with it. I liked life better when people weren't staring at me and whispering behind my back.’
‘Is that so?’ Manaro replied, amused.
Jann sighed.

‘Caro had warned me,’ he admitted, ‘I didn't take it seriously. But he was right - I'm no longer a stranger. Somehow I wasn't prepared for it. And somehow...’ He fell silent. Could he tell Manaro how much he hated those looks that disparaged him, that stared at him curiously, that passed their silent judgment on him?
Manaro understood even without words.
‘You don't like it, do you?’ he asked gently.
Jann shook his head.
‘Not really,’ he mumbled.
Manaro looked at him thoughtfully.
‘And I believe you,’ he said quietly, ‘you'd probably be much happier if it had gone on like this, wouldn't you?’
Jann raised his head.

‘No,’ he said after a moment, ‘that is, maybe for me, yes. But Acanà ... Acanà was unhappy. Now she's home, this is where she belongs. I've realized that by now, and I know she couldn't live anywhere else, not permanently. So I'll just have to learn to deal with it.’
He couldn't be any clearer than that. If Manaro had a problem with him and Acanà, then this was the template to say it loud and clear. He waited.
Manaro, on the other hand, just looked at him.
‘So young,’ he whispered, and then, louder: ‘Are you happy, my boy?’

He wasn't asking about what she'd been talking about before - Jann's discomfort at his new fame - but about what this was subliminally about. Jann thought of Acanà, and even if he had wanted to, he would not have been able to suppress his beaming grin.
‘Yes,’ he said simply, ‘very much.’
Manaro looked at him silently for a moment, his face unreadable, his eyes serious, until he finally smiled too, reached out his hand and placed it on Jann's shoulder.
‘Then it's good,’ he said.

The next day he also departed, carefully bedded in a palanquin, with many kind regards to Lijys and Torristan. As Thonash accompanied him, Jann felt as if the last of his friends was leaving him behind. Even Aruna, with her wrinkle of anger, had always stood up for him, even if it was probably for Acanà's sake. Now the only other stranger besides Jann was Akayu - and he was probably not so friendly to him.
Jann felt a little lost.

After saying goodbye, he stayed in the room, sitting on the wide windowsill, pulling his coat around him and staring outside. He could see Manaro's train in the distance, and for a moment he imagined jumping up, running off and leaving everything behind to go with the lord of the castle. But then he smiled at himself - he could never leave Acanà anyway!

As if she had read his thoughts, Acanà stepped up to him and ran her fingers tenderly through his hair. They were alone, so he took the opportunity to pull her onto his lap. After their demonstration in the courtyard, they had both held back again - or rather, they had tried to, so as not to offend people even more. Neither of them had been able to suppress their happy beams.
Jann wasn't beaming now, though, and Acanà must have noticed. She kissed him gently.
‘Are you all right?’ she asked anxiously.
Jann nodded. He had tried so hard to convince her of his maturity, he would not start now and confess his fear and discomfort to her. He had to deal with it himself - if only he knew how.
‘Everything's fine,’ he replied, snuggling up to her and burying his face against her neck for a moment to breathe in her familiar warmth.
‘I love you so much,’ he whispered. He felt her smile.
‘I love you too,’ she replied, stroking his neck and sliding her fingers lightly under the fabric of his shirt. Jann pressed a kiss to the bare skin of her neckline. Then he looked up.
‘Busy today?’ he asked without much hope.
She scrutinized him for a moment, her eyes black. He lowered his gaze.
‘You know what,’ she said suddenly, ‘I'm taking today off. One day isn't a crime, is it? I'll just quickly tell Inotaj and Akayu, and then ... what do you say we take a walk through the gardens?’
Jann still secretly dreaded the gardens, and besides, she was still within shouting distance. It was already late afternoon, but still ...
‘How about a ride instead?’ he quickly suggested.
She began to smile.
‘All right,’ she said, ‘wait here for me. Don't run away!’
He had no intention of doing so.
Acanà also returned shortly afterwards, but the ride still came to nothing. She had received Weega's call again for the first time.

‘Maraken,’ she said, ‘Jann, get some things together, I don't know how long it will take. I'm sorry. I just need to check with Akayu and Inotaj now about how things are going to work without me here.’
‘No problem,’ Jann replied with a smile, ‘I'll take care of everything. I'll wait for you in the hall as soon as the moon has risen, yes?’
She paused, taken aback by his dazzling mood. But then she realized - Jann was all about togetherness, he didn't care where or how.
She smiled too.
‘Thank you,’ she said warmly, ‘see you, my love.’
Yes, she thought silently as she ran to Akayu, she would never find a companion like Jann again.
And she hoped with a sudden force that Aruna was wrong and that Jann would never leave her.

The people of Anabellánia, the palace residents as well as Akayu and Tajla had known that their mistress was Weega's student, after all, this was the reason that had led Acanà away from her homeland. But so far, this had had no further repercussions since her return home. Now it happened for the first time that the mistress would leave, that she would leave Anabellánia with the help of the Copper Star and leave it in Akayu's care. Accordingly, both Inotaj, Akayu and Tajla accompanied her, and more than one palace resident had found an excuse to be near the hall as soon as the moon rose.

Jann was already there. He was wearing sturdy clothes, a warm cloak and had tied two small bundles. The bow was strapped to his back, the knife hung from his hip, and as he stood there patiently waiting for Acanà to clear up the last remaining details, he looked anything but insecure. In fact, for the first time since his arrival here, he seemed like the protection he had been to her in recent years and wanted to be in the future. He was not afraid.

Acanà didn't have one either. She felt a little uneasy about leaving Anabellánia, but she knew it was in good hands. She checked once more that Akayu was carrying the tip of the copper star and that the communication was working, then she approached Jann, who handed her the smaller of the two bundles.

‘Are you ready?’ she asked, and he nodded silently. She took his hand and squeezed it tightly. He returned the pressure, returned her gaze, calmly and with a certainty that made it clear to everyone for the first time that they were a unit, that they belonged together, that they would not part. For the first time, he seemed to have found his place.
Then the mistress and her shadow had disappeared.

It was just like before, Jann thought, like when they had been searching - except that no one was chasing them, that they had time and were no longer searching for anything. Acanà and he arrived in the clear moonlight outside an inn where their mission had taken them. No one had seen them, no one would suspect anything. He smiled at her, and she returned the smile.
‘An hour or two here,’ she explained, ‘then we have to move on.’
‘I see,’ he said, ‘busy night, huh? It's getting cloudy, Acanà.’ He pointed to the sky.
‘Seems like it,’ she said absently, already fully focused on her new task, ‘maybe you should get a horse. It's not far.’
‘I'll take care of it as soon as you're warm,’ he promised.

They entered the inn together, ate something together before Acanà pretended to be a simple singer and began her stories. Jann spoke briefly with the innkeeper about the horse and otherwise remained inconspicuously close to her, always keeping an eye on her listeners. He would never forget Galamind's eyrie and Acanà's warning that people who didn't want to see the truth were dangerous.

He felt at ease. For the first time in weeks, no one was staring at him, no one was whispering behind his back, and he leaned back and relaxed. The only person looking at him was a young woman whose sister was tearfully listening to Acanà's story, and she was probably only doing so because she found him attractive. Jann gave her a brief smile, whereupon she blushed and hid behind her sister. He bit his lips in amusement.

Acanà was completely absorbed in her task. He noticed it in the concentrated line of her shoulders, in the almost casual glances with which she gauged her reactions, in her well-placed words. He felt warm as he watched her and secretly vowed never to leave her alone and to lighten her burden wherever he could - even if that meant not making any demands on her and waiting until she had time for him.

The sister of the young woman who had shown such interest in Jann had apparently been her target, but after Acanà had finished with her, she took advantage of the moment and told a few more stories to the other people in the tavern. Jann paid close attention to their reactions, slipping closer to her when one of the men became agitated and placing his hand on the knife for good measure. This small gesture, although not very threatening, was enough. There were no problems until Acanà had reached the end of her stories.
‘We have to get going,’ she said kindly and stood up. Jann was already standing, bundles in hand, and asked the innkeeper for the promised horse.
‘You can't go yet,’ she asked the young woman, who had been moved to tears by her story, and her sister joined in, casting a shy glance at Jann.
Acanà shook his head.
‘It may be late,’ she said, ‘but we don't have far to go. Just across the border to Bel'lay, that's all.’
‘That might be an hour or two,’ the young woman admitted, ‘but it's so dark. How will you see the way?’
‘The light is sufficient,’ explained Acanà.
‘And the horse knows the way,’ the innkeeper added, ‘it belongs to my brother over in Bel'lay. Just let it go, it will take you safely across the roads.’
‘So you've heard,’ said Acanà with a smile.

In the meantime, Jann finished loading, slid his foot into the stirrup and sat up. He had wisely only taken one horse - they would have to leave it behind anyway, and he wanted to take the chance to hold Acanà in his arms. She stepped up to him when the young woman held her back.
‘Wait,’ she said, ‘you haven't even told us your name. You've told such wonderful stories and we don't even know who you are.’
Jann raised his head. It was not the first time she had been asked the question; he had heard it often enough before. In all her travels, she had never answered truthfully, for obvious reasons.
But now these reasons no longer existed.
Acanà seemed to have had the same thoughts as him. She turned around and smiled.
‘Of course,’ she said softly, ‘my name is Acanà. I am the mistress of Anabellánia.’
‘The mistress of ...’ the young woman began, faltered and took a deep breath.

Her sister curled her fingers into her arm and stared at Jann, who grinned mischievously at her and held out his hand to Acanà. She took it and allowed herself to be pulled into the saddle in front of him.
‘Bel'lay, huh?’ he asked.
‘Bel'lay,’ she confirmed and nestled her head against his shoulder.
Jann gave a short, amused laugh.
‘Well, then,’ he said cheerfully, ‘the horse and I will take you there safely, my love. Get some sleep, will you? I'll look after you.’
She smiled again and snuggled up to him before looking up once more.
‘Tell me,’ she said, ‘when did this actually happen?’
‘What?’ he asked.
‘This,’ she explained, digging her finger into his shirt, ‘when did my protector become my protector?’
He stared at her and then laughed happily again.
‘I don't know,’ he replied with a grin, ‘sometime between Samaya and Rawenzan, I suppose. Now go to sleep, love. I'll look after you.’
She gave in and closed her eyes. He pressed her against him, bent over the horse and gave him his heels.
Shortly afterwards, the two sisters and the landlord stood alone outside the inn, still in shock.
‘The mistress of Anabellánia,’ whispered one of the two women.
‘And her shadow,’ her sister added.
‘The student Weegas, my dears,’ the innkeeper replied slowly, ‘that means you'd better take what she told you seriously.’

The night was already well advanced when Jann reached the second inn, but the light was still on. Acanà woke up as soon as he dismounted and yawned as he led the horse past the innkeeper through the gate and into the stables. She waited for him until he had relieved the animal of its burden. She was really tired.
‘We'll stay here,’ she said firmly, ‘provided there's a room available. The nights we spent in the stables, my love, are fortunately over.’
‘Nothing against it,’ said Jann, who had learned to appreciate a good mattress.

It was already late. They got a room, but apart from that there was nothing else to do, as all the guests were already asleep. Acanà yawned again while Jann negotiated with the innkeeper, silently thinking how amazing it was how confidently and calmly he took care of all her day-to-day concerns, and how much that reassured and relieved her. She was far too exhausted to interfere.

Jann came to her as soon as he had completed the formalities and paid for the room in advance. He saw her little eyes, her brave attempt to appear awake, and he just grinned. Without a word, he scooped her up in his arms and carried her up the stairs. Acanà cuddled gratefully against his shoulder and sighed. Tomorrow, she promised herself silently, she would make it up to him - tomorrow, for sure.

She was half asleep when Jann opened the door with true acrobatic skill, laid her gently on the bed, took off her boots, cloak and weapons, and then crawled under the covers next to her to pull her lovingly into his arms.
Life is good, thought Acanà.

She almost overslept the next morning, which would have been fatal, as her mission concerned a traveler who wanted to leave the inn that morning. Acanà intercepted him just in time at breakfast, engaged him in conversation and was thus able to complete her task. However, Jann's haste to get up meant that he missed out again.
He waited silently by the door while she accompanied the guest to his horse and wished him all the best for the journey. His eyes looked thoughtful when she came back to him.
‘A merchant at odds with his brother,’ he mused, ‘do you know what will become of them?’
‘No,’ she said honestly, ‘I just know that this argument is festering and could escalate if no one intervenes. What the consequences could be - well, I'm as smart as you are.’
‘Hm,’ murmured Jann, ‘the ways of the sisters are inscrutable.’
‘You said it,’ she laughed, ‘but at least this time they led to one.’
‘And that would be?’ He turned to her, confused.
‘Well,’ she said, hanging on to him, ‘it's impossible for us to return home immediately, and I have no more orders. In other words, my love, this day is ours. What would you like to do?’
Jann stared at her, stunned. Then he began to beam.
‘I'll go and book the room,’ he said.
‘I see,’ she mocked affectionately and was delighted to see him blush.

‘No,’ he quickly defended himself, ‘not that. I mean, that too. You can be sure that will play a part today. But above all, I want ... I don't know ... Spend time with you. Talk. Laugh. Maybe dance. Anything that's possible.’
‘All right,’ she grinned, ‘but now go and book us the room. I'll find out what options there are here.’

They were lucky. In the afternoon, Acanà learned that a wedding was being celebrated in the neighboring village, to which they were cordially invited if they brought a small bridal gift, as the groom was rich. So at least the dancing was guaranteed. As far as talking was concerned, Jann and she went for a long walk after breakfast, during which they didn't talk much, but rather held hands in silence - but both felt that was enough. And as far as laughter was concerned, there was no shortage of it when they retired to their room shortly before midday.

‘We don't exactly have the right clothes for a wedding,’ Acanà said doubtfully. She stood in front of the only mirror in the room and put her hair up. Jann was still lying in bed, gazing at her lovingly and making no effort to get up. She was familiar with this - his preparations would probably be limited to putting on his clothes and combing his hair. She, on the other hand, had the strange urge to make herself beautiful for him.
‘No offense, Acanà,’ his satisfied voice sounded from the bed, ‘but if you turned up here in white clothes and a little crown on your head, everyone would look a little dismayed.’

‘Hmph,’ she grumbled, ‘I don't want to steal the bride's thunder. Besides, I don't have a little crown, you cheeky bastard. I'd just like ... I'd just rather wear something else than that.’ She pointed to her dark pants and tight tunic. It certainly wasn't festive.
‘Put some flowers in your hair,’ he suggested.
‘Flowers? Pah,’ she snorted, ‘Jann, it's a wedding. The bride has flowers in her hair, no one else does, right?’
‘And you don't want to steal her thunder,’ he added.
‘Exactly,’ she mumbled, twisting a few strands into a curl and trying to fix it on her head.
Suddenly Jann was behind her, naked, unashamed, sticking his nose between her hair.
‘Well,’ he whispered, ‘as far as I'm concerned, you've already stolen her thunder.’
He leaned forward and began to kiss her neck tenderly. She sighed involuntarily and leaned against him while his hands wandered and finally lay warmly over her breasts.
‘Hey,’ she gasped, ‘I'm already dressed!’
‘I know,’ he said, ‘but that can be changed ...’

In the end, Acanà contented herself with tying her hair back at the nape of her neck as she used to. She didn't have much more time for preparations anyway, and it wasn't important to her, because after all, she reasoned to herself, Jann saw her dressed up often enough in Anabellánia.

They were not the only guests from the inn to attend the wedding. Their gift was happily accepted, Acanà even told a few stories during the meal, and then the party began. Village musicians played, Rauúm was generously distributed and the atmosphere was great.

At first they had danced together, but soon others had found themselves demanding their rights, and although Acanà would have preferred not to let Jann out of her arms, she gave in so as not to cause displeasure. He seemed to regret it as much as she did, because even though he whirled around the dance floor with strange women and shortly afterwards became involved in a game of dice, his eyes still met hers every few moments.

The sun gradually sank, and Acanà saw it with regret. This stolen day seemed to have passed so quickly, they had experienced so little, and there was still so much she would have liked to do alone with Jann. She knew that he secretly dreaded returning to Anabellánia, where he would have to share her with all those people again, and she also knew that she couldn't put it off any longer. She could hardly justify one more night to Akayu and the Council of Sages, let alone to herself. So she extricated herself from the arms of a rather persistent admirer, who had barely let her off the dance floor, and stepped up to her young lover.
Jann looked up.

‘Hey,’ he said, grabbing her around the waist and pulling her onto his lap. He was still involved in the dice game and he had been drinking, she could smell it on his breath. She had a slight suspicion that he was working up his courage, but she didn't comment on it. Jann was still in control of his senses, and as long as he didn't talk to her about his problems in Brinan, she wouldn't either.
‘Kid, it's your turn!’ shouted one of the players, and Jann, who had been busy stroking her shoulder until then, absently reached around her for the dice.
‘A four!’ roared one of the men, ‘well, what the hell! Bad luck in the game, good luck in the ...’

Yeah, what the hell, Acanà thought with a surge of defiance. Nobody knew her here, nobody would reproach her because she had chosen this boy of all boys - and he was hers, she would not give him back, she would not let him go. She took a deep sip from his glass, then bent his head back and kissed him, kissed him with the pent-up rage, with the suppressed anger and the still insatiable desire he could ignite in her. Jann was taken aback at first, a little surprised and overwhelmed, but he quickly caught himself and returned her kiss with the same fierceness, ignoring the loud jeering of her neighbors. His dice were forgotten, his hand held her head while the other gripped her waist, and his whole body pressed against her.
‘Man, man, man,’ said one of the players, ‘you've got a crush, kid! You said it, but that it's that bad ...’
‘Don't you need to take a breath?’ another asked hypocritically.
Neither Jann nor Acanà cared. Finally, they broke away from each other breathlessly and he rested his forehead against hers.
‘We have to, don't we?’ he whispered.
‘The moon has risen,’ she returned softly, ‘oh, Jann, my Jann...’
‘Yes,’ he said and sighed, ‘but you know, it helps me to know that you'd still like to stay - at least for a little while longer.’
‘I would have loved to lock myself away with you for a few weeks,’ she confessed. I'd love to ...’
‘Me too,’ he mumbled.
Then he took a deep breath and raised his head. A round of grinning men and women looked at them. Jann sighed once more.
‘Sorry, guys,’ he said regretfully, ‘I'm getting out.’
‘I see,’ grinned his neighbor on the right, while the one on the left said mockingly: ‘We understand you.’
‘I wanted to, you really did,’ Jann murmured, ‘with the sisters, that's what I wanted.’
For a moment he looked lost, almost despondent, and Acanà's heart tightened.
‘Jann,’ she said hastily, ‘if you ...’
‘No,’ he interrupted her, ‘you're right, love. We have to go. Anabellánien ... Anabellánia has been alone for far too long.’
He gently pushed her off his lap and stood up, but his last words had not gone completely unheard. Several of the players had paused in their actions and were looking at her.
‘Anabellánia?’ said a woman, puzzled, ‘what do you have to do with Anabellánia?’

Jann and Acanà looked at each other. He seemed to regret his rash words, and she felt the same way. For some reason, she would have preferred to keep her identity to herself today - perhaps because anonymity was the only protection she could offer him. She changed the subject in the nonsensical hope of distracting people.
‘You told them you had a crush?’ she asked with raised eyebrows.
Jann shrugged his shoulders.
‘So?’
‘Well,’ she said, ‘crush isn't the word I would have chosen.’
‘Excuse me,’ she interrupted the woman, ‘Anabellánien? What does that mean?’
‘Who are you?’ one of the men asked suspiciously.
Jann, on the other hand, suddenly seemed unmoved.
‘Smitten, in love, crazy about you,’ he said, ‘what are words? You know it. I don't even need to say it anymore.’
‘Say it anyway,’ she replied, amused.

‘Fine,’ he said with a shrug, ‘I love the Lady of Anabellánia - regardless of whether she wears white robes or simple traveling clothes, whether she sits on her glass throne or travels around with me like she used to. I don't really care where we are, Acanà, but I know it doesn't matter to you. So, let's go back. You know you can't wait any longer.’
The group had fallen silent, but she paid no attention. It was unimportant who was listening to them, unimportant who was a witness. What was important was what he had said and how she reacted to it.

‘I can't change what I am,’ she replied seriously, ‘I didn't choose it, as you know only too well. I can't shirk my responsibility. But I want you to know one thing, Jann Deren: The Sisters may have given me much to bear, but they have also given me you, and with you by my side, I would take on the whole world a second time if I had to.’
She gently ran her hand along his cheek.
‘Sinaîs was right,’ she said hoarsely, ‘you were chosen for this. We belong together, my Jann, and I don't care what Thurán thinks about it.’
Jann stared at her, his eyes almost black in the yellowish firelight.
‘We belong together,’ he repeated harshly, ‘Aruna didn't call me your shadow for nothing. I will not leave you.’
He also raised his hand and put it to her face.
‘As far as it is in my power, Acanà of Anabellánia,’ he whispered, ‘I will always be by your side.’

In the weeks that followed, this became a regular occurrence. It could happen on any corner of Thurán that on a moonlit night a petite black-haired woman would suddenly appear, accompanied by a relatively silent handsome boy with startlingly blue eyes. She told stories that touched the heart, that relieved old anxieties or suddenly presented problems from a different angle. She was friendly and seemed relaxed, the boy at her side was watchful without being suspicious, and when she left, she never left indifference in her wake. The fact that she and the boy were obviously lovers could not be overlooked and perhaps seemed strange to some people at first, until they heard their names. Then most reacted with awe and understanding. Yes, they had already heard of Acanà of Anabellánien and Jann Deren, her shadow, and they would be careful not to criticize them.
So at least Jann could relax outside Anabellánia.
But then one day they came back to Maraken, spent the night there, and when Acanà woke up the next morning, Jann was gone.
